articles.headline: Providing Health Insurance Still a Struggle for Small Business
articles.snippet: A year after the insurance marketplaces were introduced as part of the Affordable Care Act, provisions meant to help small businesses offer benefits to employees have yet to fulfill their promise.
articles.abstract: A year after the insurance marketplaces were introduced as part of the Affordable Care Act, provisions meant to help small businesses offer benefits to employees have yet to fulfill their promise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brian Adams, who sells fireplaces in Indianapolis, is like many of the nation’s small-business owners. As the cost of providing health benefits has climbed, he has struggled to afford coverage for his employees — a problem the new health care law was designed, in part, to address.

articles.headline: Plan for a Times Square in Mumbai Stirs Criticism
articles.snippet: India’s government would like to boost tourism by turning a historic neighborhood into a bustling cultural hub, but many locals don’t want the noise and congestion it could bring.
articles.abstract: India’s government would like to boost tourism by turning a historic neighborhood into a bustling cultural hub, but many locals don’t want the noise and congestion it could bring.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — It was a bold, if somewhat mystifying, proposal.

articles.headline: Seeking New Tools to Address a Wage Gap
articles.snippet: Redistributing income with taxes and transfers is largely failing to close the income gap. Perhaps it’s time to try a corporate approach.
articles.abstract: Redistributing income with taxes and transfers is largely failing to close the income gap. Perhaps it’s time to try a corporate approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: What can be done about income inequality?

articles.headline: A Recent Surge of Leveraged Loans Rattles Regulators
articles.snippet: Regulators fear that the stampede into less conventional assets, including leveraged loans, could create bubbles that will later pop, harming banks and the wider economy.
articles.abstract: Regulators fear that the stampede into less conventional assets, including leveraged loans, could create bubbles that will later pop, harming banks and the wider economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: As regulators hunt for the next financial bubble, they are homing in on an obscure corner of Wall Street: the debt market where Tom Shannon’s company, a chain of flashy bowling alleys, recently borrowed nearly half a billion dollars.

articles.headline: G.M. Offers $25 Cards to Owners Who Get Ignition Switches Fixed
articles.snippet: The automaker said it would give cards that could be used at one of seven retailers to owners who get the repairs before Dec.1.
articles.abstract: The automaker said it would give cards that could be used at one of seven retailers to owners who get the repairs before Dec.1.
articles.lead_paragraph: With more than a million defective small cars still on the road, General Motors said on Tuesday that it was adding an incentive for owners to have them fixed: $25 gift cards to one of seven retailers, like Applebee’s and Bass Pro Shops.

articles.headline: To Angry Voters, Washington Comes Out the Biggest Loser
articles.snippet: Some voters said that after watching the infighting in Washington, they did not think that anything made much of a difference.
articles.abstract: Some voters said that after watching the infighting in Washington, they did not think that anything made much of a difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEAT RIDGE, Colo. — Jane Dempsey has been out of work since 2007, but she still has faith in the Colorado economy. What she has lost heart in, she said after casting her vote at the municipal building here Tuesday morning, are the public officials representing her in the nation’s capital.

articles.headline: Republicans Hold the Top 2 Prizes in Governor Races
articles.snippet: Rick Scott of Florida and Scott Walker of Wisconsin were re-elected in states that both parties are looking to as a gauge of voter sentiment in the run-up to the 2016 presidential race.
articles.abstract: Rick Scott of Florida and Scott Walker of Wisconsin were re-elected in states that both parties are looking to as a gauge of voter sentiment in the run-up to the 2016 presidential race.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans won the two most intensely followed, high-stakes governor’s races of the year as Rick Scott of Florida and Scott Walker of Wisconsin won re-election on Tuesday in states that both parties are looking to as a gauge of voter sentiment in the run-up to the 2016 presidential campaign.

articles.headline: President Obama Left Fighting for His Own Relevance
articles.snippet: The midterm elections culminated a season of discontent for President Obama — and may yet open a period of even deeper frustration in his final two years in office.
articles.abstract: The midterm elections culminated a season of discontent for President Obama — and may yet open a period of even deeper frustration in his final two years in office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two things were clear long before the votes were counted on Tuesday night: President Obama would face a Congress with more Republicans for his final two years in office, and the results would be seen as a repudiation of his leadership.

articles.headline: Republicans’ First Step Was to Handle Extremists in Party
articles.snippet: The Republican victory was the result of methodical plotting, careful candidate vetting and an abundance of preparation to ensure the party’s candidates would avoid repeating the same mistakes.
articles.abstract: The Republican victory was the result of methodical plotting, careful candidate vetting and an abundance of preparation to ensure the party’s candidates would avoid repeating the same mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was late spring, and Republican leaders knew that if they wanted to win the Senate, they needed to crush the enemy: not Democrats, but the rebels within their own party.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: After Election, Obama Vows to Work With, and Without, Congress
articles.snippet: President Obama shook off an electoral drubbing and said he was eager to find common ground, but he also vowed to bypass Congress to change the immigration system.
articles.abstract: President Obama shook off an electoral drubbing and said he was eager to find common ground, but he also vowed to bypass Congress to change the immigration system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama shook off an electoral drubbing on Wednesday and said he was eager to find common ground with Republicans during the final two years of his presidency, but he swiftly defied their objections by vowing to bypass Congress and use his executive authority to change the nation’s immigration system.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Peter Baker
